<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 186, 171, 201]]<|/det|>
# PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 206, 366, 222]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Multiple Choice (Extended)  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 247, 560, 291]]<|/det|>
Additional Materials: Multiple Choice Answer Sheet Soft clean eraser Soft pencil (type B or HB recommended)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 312, 388, 329]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 342, 237, 357]]<|/det|>
Write in soft pencil.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 357, 504, 372]]<|/det|>
Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 372, 892, 401]]<|/det|>
Write your name, centre number and candidate number on the Answer Sheet in the spaces provided unless this has been done for you.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 400, 383, 415]]<|/det|>
DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 429, 892, 459]]<|/det|>
There are forty questions on this paper. Answer all questions. For each question there are four possible answers A, B, C and D.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 458, 890, 475]]<|/det|>
Choose the one you consider correct and record your choice in soft pencil on the separate Answer Sheet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 488, 556, 504]]<|/det|>
Read the instructions on the Answer Sheet very carefully.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 517, 765, 533]]<|/det|>
Each correct answer will score one mark. A mark will not be deducted for a wrong answer.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 533, 467, 548]]<|/det|>
Any rough working should be done in this booklet.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 548, 359, 563]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 562, 630, 578]]<|/det|>
Take the weight of \(1.0\mathrm{kg}\) to be \(10\mathrm{N}\) (acceleration of free fall \(= 10\mathrm{m / s}^2\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 72, 99, 88]]<|/det|>

The density of the liquid is \(1200 \text{kg} / \text{m}^3\). <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 464, 549, 482]]<|/det|> What is the pressure on the object due to the liquid? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 491, 138, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 492, 210, 509]]<|/det|> 600 Pa <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[280, 492, 298, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[311, 492, 390, 509]]<|/det|> 2400 Pa <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[448, 492, 468, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[480, 492, 568, 509]]<|/det|> 60 000 Pa <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[615, 492, 635, 509]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[640, 492, 747, 509]]<|/det|> 240 000 Pa <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 536, 106, 555]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 536, 618, 555]]<|/det|> Which statement about the evaporation of a liquid is correct? <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 565, 134, 583]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 565, 920, 597]]<|/det|> The least energetic molecules escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 606, 133, 624]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 606, 920, 638]]<|/det|> The least energetic molecules escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 648, 133, 666]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 648, 920, 680]]<|/det|> The most energetic molecules escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid decreases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 689, 133, 707]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 689, 920, 721]]<|/det|> The most energetic molecules escape from the surface and the temperature of the liquid increases. <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 749, 104, 766]]<|/det|> <|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 749, 920, 781]]<|/det|> A bubble of gas is formed deep under water. <label>18</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 222, 920, 256]]<|/det|>
A liquid turns into a gas. This occurs only at one particular temperature, and the change happens throughout the liquid.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 268, 351, 286]]<|/det|>
What is this process called?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 297, 133, 314]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 297, 210, 314]]<|/det|>

<label>19</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 418, 905, 452]]<|/det|>
One end of a rod of copper is placed in hot water. Thermal energy travels along the rod to make the other end warmer.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 463, 892, 497]]<|/det|>
What is the behaviour of the copper at an atomic level that accounts for most of the transfer of thermal energy from one end to the other?

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 507, 133, 525]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 507, 761, 526]]<|/det|>
Atoms at the hot end gain kinetic energy and move towards the other end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 535, 133, 552]]<|/det|>
<label>B</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 534, 811, 552]]<|/det|>
Atoms at the hot end expand, colliding with other atoms and transferring energy.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 561, 131, 579]]<|/det|>
<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 561, 881, 593]]<|/det|>
Free electrons at the hot end gain energy and move towards the other end, colliding with atoms along the rod.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 602, 133, 618]]<|/det|>
<label>D</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 602, 898, 634]]<|/det|>
Free electrons at the hot end gain energy from the hot water and move directly to the other end.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 660, 106, 677]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 588, 680, 607]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[112, 617, 134, 636]]<|/det|>
<label>A</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 617, 598, 636]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 644, 574, 662]]<|/det|>

<label>C</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 670, 567, 688]]<|/det|>
Lead increases the half-life of radioactive sources.
